lest you learn his ways
    and get a snare to your soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be one of those who shakes hands in a pledge,
    or of those who use securities for debts;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if you have nothing to pay,
    why should he take away your bed from under you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not remove the ancient landmark
    which your fathers have set.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
When you sit to eat with a ruler,
    consider diligently what is before you;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and put a knife to your throat,
    if you are a man given to appetite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be not desirous of his delicacies,
    for they are deceptive food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not labor to be rich;
    cease from your own wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not eat the bread of him who has an evil eye,
    neither desire his delicacies;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for as he thinks in his heart,
    so is he.
“Eat and drink!” he says to you,
    but his heart is not with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The morsel you have eaten, you will vomit up,
    and lose your sweet words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not speak in the ears of a fool,
    for he will despise the wisdom of your words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not remove the old landmark,
    nor enter the fields of the fatherless;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for their Redeemer is mighty;
    He will plead their cause with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Apply your heart to instruction,
    and your ears to the words of knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not withhold correction from a child,
    for if you beat him with the rod, he will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You shall beat him with the rod,
    and deliver his soul from death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, if your heart is wise,
    my heart will rejoice—even mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, my inmost being will rejoice
    when your lips speak right things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not let your heart envy sinners,
    but continue in the fear of the Lord all day long;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for surely there is an end,
    and your expectation will not be cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear, my son, and be wise;
    and guide your heart in the way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be among winebibbers,
    among riotous eaters of meat;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty,
    and drowsiness will clothe a man with rags.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to your father who gave you life,
    and do not despise your mother when she is old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Buy the truth, and do not sell it,
    also wisdom and instruction and understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The father of the righteous will greatly rejoice,
    and he who fathers a wise child will have joy of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your father and your mother will be glad,
    and she who bore you will rejoice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, give me your heart,
    and let your eyes observe my ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For a prostitute is a deep ditch,
    and a seductress is a narrow pit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She also lies in wait as for a prey,
    and increases the transgressors among men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has woe? Who has sorrow?
    Who has contentions? Who has babbling?
    Who has wounds without cause? Who has redness of eyes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who tarry long at the wine,
    those who go to seek mixed wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
at the last it bites like a serpent,
    and stings like a viper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your eyes will see strange things,
    and your heart will utter perverse things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, you will be as he who lies down in the midst of the sea,
    or as he who lies upon the top of a mast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They have stricken me,” you will say, “and I was not sick;
    they have beaten me, and I did not feel it.
When will I awake?
    I will seek it yet again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be envious against evil men,
    nor desire to be with them;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for their heart studies destruction,
    and their lips talk of mischief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through wisdom is a house built,
    and by understanding it is established;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and by knowledge the rooms will be filled
    with all precious and pleasant riches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wise man is strong;
    yes, a man of knowledge increases strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For by wise counsel you will wage your war,
    and in multitude of counselors there is safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom is too high for a fool;
    he does not open his mouth in the gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who devises to do evil
    will be called a schemer of plots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The thought of foolishness is sin,
    and the scorner is an abomination to men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you faint in the day of adversity,
    your strength is small.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you refrain to deliver those who are drawn unto death,
    and those who are ready to be slain;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if you say, “Surely we did not know this,”
    does not He who ponders the heart consider it?
And He who keeps your soul, does He not know it?
    And will He not render to every man according to his works?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, eat honey because it is good,
    and the honeycomb that is sweet to your taste;
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not lie in wait, O wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous;
    do not spoil his resting place;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for a just man falls seven times and rises up again,
    but the wicked will fall into mischief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not rejoice when your enemy falls,
    and do not let your heart be glad when he stumbles;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
lest the Lord see it, and it displease Him,
    and He turn away His wrath from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not fret because of evil men,
    nor be envious of the wicked;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for there will be no reward to the evil man;
    the candle of the wicked will be put out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, fear the Lord and the king;
    and do not meddle with those who are given to change;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for their calamity will rise suddenly,
    and who knows the ruin of them both?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These things also belong to the wise:
It is not good to show partiality in judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who says to the wicked, “You are righteous,”
    him the people will curse; nations will abhor him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But to those who rebuke him will be delight,
    and a good blessing will come upon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every man will kiss his lips
    that gives a right answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause,
    and do not deceive with your lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, “I will do so to him as he has done to me;
    I will render to the man according to his work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I went by the field of the slothful,
    and by the vineyard of the man void of understanding;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and it was all grown over with thorns,
    and nettles covered its surface,
    and the stone wall was broken down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I saw, and considered it;
    I looked on it and received instruction:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet a little sleep, a little slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to sleep,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so your poverty will come like a stalker,
    and your need as an armed man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are also proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is the glory of God to conceal a thing,
    but the honor of kings is to search out a matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the heaven for height, and the earth for depth,
    so the heart of kings is unsearchable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take away the dross from the silver,
    and there will come forth a vessel for the refiner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take away the wicked from before the king,
    and his throne will be established in righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not exalt yourself in the presence of the king,
    and do not stand in the place of great men;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for it is better that it be said to you, “Come up here,”
    than that you should be put lower in the presence of the prince,
    whom your eyes have seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Debate your cause with your neighbor himself,
    and do not disclose a secret to another;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
lest he who hears it put you to shame,
    and your reputation be ruined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A word fitly spoken
    is like apples of gold in settings of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold,
    so is a wise reprover to an obedient ear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the cold of snow in the time of harvest,
    so is a faithful messenger to those who send him,
    for he refreshes the soul of his masters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever boasts himself of a false gift
    is like clouds and wind without rain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By long forbearing is a prince persuaded,
    and a soft tongue breaks the bone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you found honey? Eat only as much as is sufficient for you,
    lest you be filled with it and vomit it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Withdraw your foot from your neighbor’s house,
    lest he be weary of you and so hate you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who bears false witness against his neighbor
    is like a club, a sword, and a sharp arrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble
    is like a broken tooth and a foot out of joint.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As he who takes away a garment in cold weather,
    and as vinegar on soda,
    so is he who sings songs to a heavy heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat;
    and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for you will heap coals of fire upon his head,
    and the Lord will reward you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The north wind brings rain,
    and a backbiting tongue an angry countenance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to dwell in the corner of the housetop
    than with a brawling woman in a wide house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As cold waters to a thirsty soul,
    so is good news from a far country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A righteous man falling down before the wicked
    is as a troubled fountain and a corrupt spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not good to eat much honey;
    so for men to search their own glory is not glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who has no rule over his own spirit
    is like a city that is broken down and without walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest,
    so honor is not seemly for a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the bird by flitting, as the swallow by flying,
    so the curse without cause will not alight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
    and a rod for the fool’s back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not answer a fool according to his folly,
    lest you also be like unto him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Answer a fool according to his folly,
    lest he be wise in his own conceit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who sends a message by the hand of a fool
    cuts off the feet and drinks violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The legs of the lame are not equal;
    so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As he who binds a stone in a sling,
    so is he who gives honor to a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a thorn goes into the hand of a drunkard,
    so is a parable in the mouth of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The great God who formed all things
    rewards the fool and rewards the transgressor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a dog returns to its vomit,
    so a fool returns to his folly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see a man wise in his own conceit?
    There is more hope for a fool than for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The slothful man says, “There is a lion in the way!
    A lion is in the streets!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the door turns upon his hinges,
    so does the slothful upon his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The slothful buries his hand in his bowl;
    it grieves him to bring it again to his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit
    than seven men who can answer reasonably.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who passes by and meddles with strife not belonging to him
    is like one who takes a dog by the ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a madman who casts
    firebrands, arrows, and death,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so is the man who deceives his neighbor,
    and says, “I was only joking.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where there is no wood, the fire goes out;
    so where there is no talebearer, the strife ceases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As charcoal is to burning coals, and wood to fire,
    so is a contentious man to kindle strife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of a talebearer are as wounds,
    and go down into the innermost parts of the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Burning lips and a wicked heart
    are like earthenware covered with silver dross.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who hates dissembles with his lips,
    and lays up deceit within him;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when he speaks kindly, do not believe him,
    for there are seven abominations in his heart;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
though his hatred is covered by deceit,
    his wickedness will be shown before the whole congregation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it,
    and he who rolls a stone, it will return upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lying tongue hates those who are afflicted by it,
    and a flattering mouth works ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not boast about tomorrow,
    for you do not know what a day may bring forth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let another man praise you, and not your own mouth;
    a stranger, and not your own lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A stone is heavy and the sand weighty,
    but a fool’s wrath is heavier than them both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous,
    but who is able to stand before envy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open rebuke is better
    than secret love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Faithful are the wounds of a friend,
    but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The full soul loathes a honeycomb,
    but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a bird that wanders from her nest,
    so is a man who wanders from his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart,
    so does the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
My son, be wise, and make my heart glad,
    that I may answer him who reproaches me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A prudent man foresees the evil and hides himself,
    but the simple pass on and are punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take his garment that is security for a stranger,
    and take a pledge of him for an adulterous woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning,
    it will be counted a curse to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A continual dripping on a very rainy day
    and a contentious woman are alike;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
whoever restrains her restrains the wind,
    and grasps oil in his right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Iron sharpens iron,
    so a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever keeps the fig tree will eat its fruit;
    so he who waits on his master will be honored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As in water face answers to face,
    so the heart of man to man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Death and destruction are never full;
    so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the refining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold,
    so is a man to his praise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though you should grind a fool in a mortar
    among wheat with a pestle,
    yet his foolishness will not depart from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be diligent to know the state of your flocks,
    and look well to your herds;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for riches are not forever,
    nor does the crown endure to every generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The hay appears, and the tender grass shows itself,
    and herbs of the mountains are gathered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lambs are for your clothing,
    and the goats are the price of the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked flee when no man pursues,
    but the righteous are bold as a lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because of the transgression of a land, many are its princes;
    but by a man of understanding and knowledge, it shall be prolonged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A poor man who oppresses the poor
    is like a sweeping rain that leaves no food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who forsake instruction praise the wicked,
    but such as keep instruction contend with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Evil men do not understand justice,
    but those who seek the Lord understand all things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better is the poor who walks in his uprightness
    than he who is perverse in his ways, though he be rich.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever keeps the law is a wise son,
    but he who is a companion of riotous men shames his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who by usury and unjust gain increases his substance
    will gather it for him who will pity the poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who turns away his ear from hearing instruction,
    even his prayer will be an abomination.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The rich man is wise in his own conceit,
    but the poor who has understanding searches him out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When righteous men rejoice, there is great glory;
    but when the wicked rise, a man hides himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who covers his sins will not prosper,
    but whoever confesses and forsakes them will have mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Happy is the man who always fears,
    but he who hardens his heart will fall into mischief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a roaring lion and a charging bear,
    so is a wicked ruler over the poor people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The prince who lacks understanding is also a great oppressor,
    but he who hates covetousness will prolong his days.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever walks uprightly will be saved,
    but he who is perverse in his ways will fall at once.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who tills his land will have plenty of bread,
    but he who follows after vain things will have poverty enough.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A faithful man will abound with blessings,
    but he who makes haste to be rich will not be innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To show partiality is not good,
    because for a morsel of bread that man will transgress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who hastens to be rich has an evil eye,
    and does not consider that poverty will come upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who rebukes a man will find more favor afterward
    than he who flatters with the tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever robs his father or his mother
    and says, “It is no transgression,”
    the same is the companion of a destroyer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who is of a proud heart stirs up strife,
    but he who puts his trust in the Lord will prosper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who trusts in his own heart is a fool,
    but whoever walks wisely will be delivered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who gives to the poor will not lack,
    but he who hides his eyes will have many a curse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked rise, men hide themselves;
    but when they perish, the righteous increase.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who is often reproved, yet hardens his neck,
    will suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice;
    but when the wicked rule, the people mourn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever loves wisdom rejoices his father,
    but he who keeps company with harlots spends his substance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king establishes the land by judgment,
    but he who receives bribes overthrows it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who flatters his neighbor
    spreads a net for his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare,
    but the righteous sing and rejoice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The righteous considers the cause of the poor,
    but the wicked regards not to know it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Scornful men bring a city into a snare,
    but wise men turn away wrath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a wise man contends with a foolish man,
    whether he rage or laugh, there is no rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The bloodthirsty hate the upright,
    but the just seek his soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fool utters all his mind,
    but a wise man keeps it in until afterwards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a ruler listens to lies,
    all his servants are wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The poor and the deceitful man have this in common:
    The Lord gives light to the eyes of both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king who faithfully judges the poor,
    his throne will be established forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rod and reproof give wisdom,
    but a child left to himself brings his mother to shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked are multiplied, transgression increases;
    but the righteous will see their fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Correct your son, and he will give you rest;
    yes, he will give delight to your soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where there is no vision, the people perish;
    but happy is he who keeps the teaching.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A servant will not be corrected by words,
    for though he understands he will not answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see a man who is hasty in his words?
    There is more hope for a fool than for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who delicately brings up his servant from a child
    will have him as a son in the end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An angry man stirs up strife,
    and a furious man abounds in transgression.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man’s pride will bring him low,
    but honor will uphold the humble in spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whoever is partner with a thief hates his own soul;
    he hears the oath but tells nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fear of man brings a snare,
    but whoever puts his trust in the Lord will be safe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many seek the ruler’s favor,
    but every man’s judgment comes from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An unjust man is an abomination to the just,
    and he who is upright in the way is an abomination to the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, the oracle.
The man declares to Ithiel,
    to Ithiel and Ukal:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely I am more brutish than any man,
    and have not the understanding of a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I neither learned wisdom,
    nor have the knowledge of the holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has ascended up into heaven, or descended?
    Who has gathered the wind in his fists?
Who has bound the waters in a garment?
    Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is His name, and what is the name of His son,
    if you know?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every word of God is pure;
    He is a shield to those who put their trust in Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not add to His words,
    lest He reprove you, and you be found a liar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Two things I have required of you;
    do not deny me them before I die:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
lest I be full, and deny You,
    and say, “Who is the Lord?”
or lest I be poor, and steal,
    and take the name of my God in vain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not accuse a servant to his master,
    lest he curse you, and you be found guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a generation that curses their father,
    and does not bless its mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a generation that is pure in its own eyes,
    and yet is not washed from its filthiness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a generation—oh, how lofty are their eyes!
    And their eyelids are lifted up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a generation whose teeth are as swords,
    and their jaw teeth as knives,
to devour the poor from off the earth,
    and the needy from among men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The leech has two daughters,
    crying, “Give, give.” 
There are three things that are never satisfied,
    indeed, four things never say, “It is enough”:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the grave, the barren womb,
    the earth that is not filled with water,
    and the fire that never says, “It is enough.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eye that mocks at his father,
    and despises to obey his mother,
the ravens of the valley will pick it out,
    and the young eagles will eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are three things which are too wonderful for me,
    indeed, four which I do not know:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the way of an eagle in the air,
    the way of a serpent on a rock,
the way of a ship in the midst of the sea,
    and the way of a man with a maid.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For three things the earth is disquieted,
    and for four which it cannot bear:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for a servant when he reigns,
    and a fool when he is filled with food,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for a hateful woman when she is married,
    and a handmaid who is heir to her mistress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are four things which are little upon the earth,
    but they are exceeding wise:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ants are a people not strong,
    yet they prepare their food in the summer;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the badgers are but a feeble folk,
    yet they make their houses in the rocks;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the locusts have no king,
    yet they go forth all of them by bands;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the spider takes hold with her hands,
    and is in kings’ palaces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are three things which go well,
    indeed, four are comely in going:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a lion which is strongest among beasts,
    and does not turn away for any;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a strutting rooster, a male goat also,
    and a king, against whom there is no rising up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have been foolish in lifting up yourself,
    or if you have thought evil,
    put your hand on your mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely the churning of milk brings forth butter,
    and the wringing of the nose brings forth blood,
    so the forcing of wrath brings forth strife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of King Lemuel, an oracle that his mother taught him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What, my son? And what, the son of my womb?
    And what, the son of my vows?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not give your strength to women,
    nor your ways to that which destroys kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
lest they drink and forget the law,
    and pervert the justice of any of the afflicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give strong drink to him who is ready to perish,
    and wine to those who are of heavy hearts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let him drink, and forget his poverty,
    and remember his misery no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open your mouth for the speechless
    in the cause of all such as are appointed to destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open your mouth, judge righteously,
    and plead the cause of the poor and needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can find a virtuous woman?
    For her worth is far above rubies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heart of her husband safely trusts in her,
    so that he will have no lack of gain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She will do him good and not evil
    all the days of her life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She seeks wool and flax,
    and works willingly with her hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is like the merchant ships,
    she brings her food from afar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She also rises while it is yet night,
    and gives food to her household,
    and a portion to her maidens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She considers a field and buys it;
    with the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She clothes herself with strength,
    and strengthens her arms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She perceives that her merchandise is good;
    her candle does not go out by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She lays her hands to the spindle,
    and her hands hold the distaff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She stretches out her hand to the poor;
    yes, she reaches forth her hands to the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is not afraid of the snow for her household,
    for all her household are clothed with scarlet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes herself coverings of tapestry;
    her clothing is silk and purple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her husband is known in the gates,
    when he sits among the elders of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes fine linen and sells it,
    and delivers sashes to the merchant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strength and honor are her clothing,
    and she will rejoice in time to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She opens her mouth with wisdom,
    and in her tongue is the teaching of kindness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She looks well to the ways of her household,
    and does not eat the bread of idleness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her children rise up and call her blessed;
    her husband also, and he praises her:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Many daughters have done virtuously,
    but you excel them all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Charm is deceitful, and beauty is vain,
    but a woman who fears the Lord, she shall be praised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give her of the fruit of her hands,
    and let her own works praise her in the gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator
